Erik.Action: Fumbles trying to hold his sword to Helga's throat while undoing his trousers, showing clumsiness in a threatening situation.
Claims confidently to have experience looting and pillaging, trying to appear capable and intimidating.
Covers Helga's mouth to prevent her from speaking and tries to make sure no one has heard, showing some situational awareness.
Hesitates and shows uncertainty about his intentions and feelings, struggles to respond confidently to Helga's pointed questions.
Admits frankly that he prefers mutual feelings and hesitates before acting, showing some self-awareness and restraint despite difficult circumstances.
Threatens Helga with a confused and contradictory statement about 'not raping' her, indicating poor communication and lack of clear confidence.
Explains pragmatically that killing and looting are necessary to fund further expeditions, demonstrating practical reasoning and goal-oriented thinking.
Says 'Stop talking as if we were married!' in frustration to Helga.
Says 'I just said I didn't feel like raping you.' as a crude joke during argument.
Vents frustration on a door after conversation with Helga.
Thanks Helga for saving his face by lying about the 'rape' comment.
Leaps to Helga's defense and pulls Jennifer off when she attacks Helga.
Leaps to Helga's defense, pulls Jennifer off her.
Runs Jennifer through during a fight, staining dough with blood.
Runs Ernest through without hesitation while still on top of Helga.
Accidentally runs Helga through, causing her fatal injury.
Cradles Helga's head and tries helplessly to staunch her bleeding.
Expresses confusion and concern about Helga's false accusation and imminent death.
Asks Helga for her name as she dies, showing desire for connection.
Leaps to Helga's defense and fights Jennifer, ultimately running Jennifer through.
Without hesitation, runs Ernest through to stop him.
Accidentally runs Helga through while trying to save her.
Quickly reacts by kneeling to try to staunch Helga's bleeding and cradles her head.
Fails to get Helga's name before she dies and is left holding the consequences of the violence around him, showing a mix of helplessness and confusion.
Frowns disapprovingly at the Vikings hurling axes at a frightened girl, showing discomfort with their cruel behavior.
Frowns at the drunken Vikings throwing axes dangerously at a young girl, showing disapproval of reckless behavior.
Questions the purpose of their violent and brutal lifestyle, expressing doubt and reflection.
Admits to killing a girl, seemingly shocked and distressed by his own action.
Runs calling out for Freya, showing concern and urgency to find her.
Pauses to consider the moral and existential implications of Viking life, showing reflective thinking.
Stops abruptly when admitting to killing Freya, shocked by his own actions, indicating internal conflict and some hesitancy.
Calls out for Freya and pursues her into a remote mountainside and cave, showing decisive action and determination.
Engages sincerely with Freya, listens to her stories and questions about the world
Admits uncertainty and vulnerability ('I shouldn't have come')
Earnestly asks Freya if there is anything men can do to prevent Ragnarok, shows determination to act.
Pushes through a crowd to separate two fighting men, intervenes to stop violence.
Determines that it is the Age of Ragnarok and seeks out Freya to understand what can be done.
Declares he will go and wake the gods up, showing earnest enthusiasm and confidence.
Asks Freya for specific instructions and listens carefully, demonstrating willingness to learn and prepare.
Hesitates briefly after hearing the dangers of the Horn Resounding, showing some prudence and thoughtfulness.
Pushes through a crowd to separate two fighting warriors, taking initiative to de-escalate conflict.
Dives back to keep antagonists apart.
Proposes a dangerous but peaceful solution where nobody gets killed.
Physically intervenes to stop fighting by laying out both antagonists.
Challenges others, asking if they are afraid to try, pushing others to act.
Encourages the others to attempt the impossible journey, shows determination and inspires group despite doubts.
Grins after persuading others against their initial reluctance, indicating a playful or good-natured manner.
Is referenced as having the potential to find the Horn Resounding, cross the Rainbow Bridge, and awaken the gods, suggesting a significant destiny but with no direct action shown here.
Addresses the villagers before departure, trying to comfort them despite their sorrow and tears.
Initially gives a brief farewell, seeming hesitant and awkward before expanding on his speech.
Attempts to rally the villagers with a speech before departure, expressing awareness of dangers and encouraging courage.
Fails to initially deliver a confident or inspiring speech, resulting in widespread crying and emotional upset among the villagers.
Smiles broadly and waves to the grieving villagers, trying to be cheerful despite the sadness.
Pleases the crowd by asking them to keep calm and reassuring them that not all will die horribly.
Unable to think of anything truly cheerful to say, resorts to a superficial 'Cheers everybody!'.
Turns for a last salute and tries to offer a hopeful farewell despite the grim situation.
Turns to his Grandad for guidance when unsure what to say to the distraught villagers.
Attempts to cheer up the crowd despite being unable to think of anything better than 'Cheers everybody!'.
Tries to calm everyone down by reminding them not all may die and that deaths may not be hideous.
Stops himself from saying potentially demoralizing words when Grandad advises him to stop.
Responds respectfully and attentively when Keitel Blacksmith intervenes and explains his importance.
Reassures women that Keitel's assistant Loki can do the blacksmithing tasks despite their doubts.
Interrupts and scolds men quarrelling over a seat, trying to calm a petty dispute.
Insists Sven's father sit despite limited space and tensions, organizes seating strictly.
Tells Sven's father to 'shut up' and commands seating arrangements firmly.
Organizes seating arrangements methodically, paying attention to interpersonal dynamics and adjusting seating to minimize conflict.
Accepts input from others (e.g., Snorri) but ultimately makes decisions confidently and asserts control.
Dismisses minor aesthetic concerns (beards vs. moustaches) to focus on more important matters, showing practical judgment.
Uses curt language ('Shut up') towards Sven's dad, which may undermine leadership through respect.
Reluctantly accepts his mother's pillow, a treasured object from his father, showing respect and openness to family tradition despite embarrassment.
Embarrassed by his mother’s public intervention but responds without anger; shows tolerance and acceptance of her care.
Raises a half-goodbye to the girl he killed, indicating a moment of reflection and possible remorse or respect.
Reluctantly accepts the pillow from his mother after initial hesitation, showing some practical acceptance despite embarrassment.
Raises his hand to half-goodbye to the girl he killed, showing emotional awareness but not necessarily competence.
Gives a confident shout to commence the rowing and start the voyage, demonstrating leadership and decisive action.
Notices the sinister sail on the horizon and commands the crew to break out the oars despite most being sea-sick.
Insists on immediate action and motivates the reluctant crew to row even though they are feeling ill.
Gives orders clearly and authoritatively to Thorfinn and Keitel, ensuring cooperation.
Manhandles Ivar to take up drumming, pushing him despite Ivar's illness.
Encourages rowing and tries to motivate the crew during pursuit, reacting to Ivar's wavering.
Grins encouragingly at scared Vikings and urges them to row faster despite danger.
Leans on the steering oar and silences Ivar's drum to calm the situation.
Tries repeatedly to use the lodestone to find direction, then gives up without frustration or blame.
Shares discovery of 'The Gates of the World' and the unknown with the others, expressing wonder together.
Questions the nature of the sun when it behaves unusually ('Should the sun do that?'), showing observation and critical thinking.
Warns others to 'Look out!' before the monster attacks, demonstrating alertness and quick response.
Calmly instructs the crew to row at a manageable speed to maintain order during the panic.
Commands the crew to row but notices they're going too fast and instructs them to slow down to a manageable pace.
Repeatedly corrects Ivar's frantic drumming pace to maintain order despite the panic.
Commands his crew to keep rowing amid panic and danger, trying to maintain order.
Holds up the pillow given by his mother as a source of hope and protection for the crew.
Focuses on saving the situation and supporting his terror-stricken crew.
Commands crew to row faster and keep up the strike against the dragon.
Observes terror-stricken crew and realizes he must save the situation.
Has sudden idea to use pillow given by mother as a solution.
Drops rowing momentarily to retrieve pillow and climb mast.
Climbs to the top of the mast and boldly swings onto the monster's nose to take action against the Dragon.
Shoves a pillow up the Dragon's nostril and encourages it to breathe, showing a mix of boldness and a somewhat humorous approach.
Commands the crew to hold tight during the Dragon's sneeze, tries to keep order during crisis.
Shows visible concern for the crew's safety, warns them to get back to avoid falling.
Does not visibly panic or shout selfishly, but struggles physically, still trying to manage situation.
Commands others to hold tight during the Dragon's sneeze, showing quick thinking under pressure.
Leaps back across the mast to avoid the blast, demonstrating physical agility and situational awareness.
Tries to prevent the crew from all rushing to one side, attempting to maintain balance and order on the boat.
Fails to prevent the boat from tipping, leading to crew members falling into the sea.
Ends up dislodged and hanging precariously by his hands, unable to regain secure footing quickly.
Despite the situation, continues to give commands and tries to manage the crisis.
After falling into the ship and causing a hole, quickly removes his helmet and starts bailing water, encouraging others to do the same.
Despite being dislodged and falling awkwardly into the ship’s hull, Erik quickly recovers, removes his helmet, and begins bailing water to save the ship.
Hangs on precariously high up the mast, risking personal safety in a dangerous situation.
Encourages the group by affirming they have at least tried and will die like men.
Urgently asks Thorfinn not to let him drown, showing trust and reliance on comrades.
Pauses in the ritual killing and looks around, showing awareness and possibly consideration beyond immediate violence.
Stops the Vikings from killing each other when stranded in water.
Calms others in panic by reassuring about the blue sky and sun.
Orders to get weapons from the unconscious girl, assumes she is dangerous without evidence.
Tells everyone not to kill anyone as realization dawns, showing control and leadership.
Carefully observes the environment and corrects the panic about a dragon, identifying the sun and clarifying the situation.
Instructs to get weapons from the girl despite her being unarmed, showing cautiousness and preparedness.
Refuses to immediately resort to violence and instead suggests making friends with the unknown girl.
Questions and challenges the group's assumptions about their situation and the place (Hy-Brasil), showing curiosity and critical thinking.
Expresses suspicion and caution upon hearing 'welcome', indicating awareness and carefulness in an uncertain situation.
Listens patiently to Aud's warnings about swords spilling blood.
Admits ignorance when told about the curse on Hy-Brasil and its impact.
Shows curiosity and openness by asking questions about the curse without hostility.
Responds politely to King Arnulf's offer to sing despite their haste.
Interrupts King Arnulf to insist 'OBVIOUSLY there's no killing.'
Interrupts King Arnulf and dismisses the idea of no killing as 'OBVIOUSLY' unrealistic.
Politely but firmly tries to steer the conversation back to his quest despite distractions.
Pauses and seems hesitant when explaining about the Horn Resounding.
Diplomatically asks King Arnulf and his court to sing, despite not genuinely wanting to hear the singing, then admits he is lying
Smiles reassuringly at the King before the musicians perform, showing support despite the anticipated poor performance.
Responds to the King’s despair about the music with a polite and encouraging comment: 'No, no... It was very... er, nice.'
Smiles reassuringly at the King and the musicians despite the awful din, attempting to stay composed and supportive.
Responds diplomatically to King Arnulf's despair about their musical ability, showing social tact.
Decides to be honest about not liking the music despite the risk of offending the King.
Acknowledges the difficulty of diplomacy and tries to shift focus to the quest for the Horn Resounding.
Fails to smoothly manage the social situation, seeming to make a mess of diplomacy.
Openly discusses feelings of love with Aud, showing vulnerability and engagement in sincere emotional exchange.
Repeatedly focuses on physical aspect (bed) rather than expressing feelings directly, possibly deflecting or showing discomfort with emotional honesty.
Engages in a hesitant and confused conversation with Aud about love and fidelity, focusing more on literal meanings than emotional understanding.
Responds quickly to the sound of Ivar's horn and immediately looks out the window to identify the approaching ship, showing situational awareness and responsiveness.
Blurts out 'Fifth...' revealing a secret despite urging to stay quiet
Blurts out 'Fifth...' against advice, revealing information and risking exposure.
Instinctively cowers out of the way when the King approaches, showing self-preservation.
Jokes lightly about the cloak his mother gave him despite Aud's sincerity
Allows Aud to put her arms around him and listens to her sincere offer to help him get to Asgaard
Shows internal conflict and uncertainty whether to trust Aud's offer
Leaps out of the way to avoid conflict but accidentally knocks a chest, creating a minor disruption.
Displays skepticism about the significance of the Cloak Invisible, doubting its special nature.
Is torn and unsure whether to believe Aud's sincere offer to help him get to Asgaard.
Urgently warns others about the danger posed by Halfdan the Black and struggles to prevent him from landing.
Insists on being released and argues passionately despite being restrained and treated roughly.
Shows little patience with the King's musicians and King Arnulf by interrupting and expressing frustration.
Expresses concern for safety and tries to warn about Halfdan the Black's threat
Urgently asks to be released from the musicians, indicating distress
Tries to appeal to King Arnulf to avoid death and danger
Looks shocked at Thorfinn's strange feeling, showing empathy and connection
Questions Sven's Dad's talk about magic skeptically
Calms his fearful crew by rationally explaining that the opposing ship's power is a trick, not magic.
Realizes he is the only one who can save the situation and takes initiative to confront the challenge.
Unexpectedly asks Aud for help after struggling to climb the walls, showing vulnerability and trust.
Rather miffed when Aud points out that he could have used the stairs and put himself in danger.
Insists on taking action to stop Halfdan despite warnings, showing resolve and responsibility for the group
Grabs and uses the Cloak Invisible without fully understanding its limitation and despite Aud's warning
Races over and grabs the cloak, then jumps out of a forty-foot window parachuting down safely using the cloak
Acts with confidence and decisiveness to stop Halfdan by returning to his ship quickly
Fails to understand the cloak only works on Aud's father, missing an important detail despite warnings
Leaps into the Golden Dragon brandishing the Cloak Invisible with boldness.
Responds to a challenge about magic in a confident and somewhat playful manner.
Shows leadership by urging the crew to row without hesitation.
Uses the Cloak Invisible confidently as a magic to match Halfdan's magic.
Commands the crew promptly with 'To the oars!' showing decisiveness and leadership.
Grins round at his men triumphantly, imagining he has vanished from their sight using the Cloak Invisible
Uses the Cloak Invisible to create an illusion of vanishing, impressing his men and confusing the enemy.
Leaps confidently onto Halfdan's ship after the collision, demonstrating bravery and tactical initiative.
Enjoys the moment of suspense and theatrics rather than focusing solely on practical impact.
Makes silly faces at a dog-soldier and playfully taunts the enemy to distract them and create chaos.
Breaks into a little dance and makes light of a dangerous situation, showing friendliness and good-natured behavior even amidst conflict.
Shows no fear and behaves lightheartedly during a tense battle, which might be perceived as insensitivity to the severity of the situation.
Leaps onto enemy ship confidently and intimidates dog-soldiers with playful antics, causing confusion and disarray among the enemy.
Behaves playfully and silly during combat, assuming invisibility which is not actually true.
Runs fearlessly among dog-soldiers, shows playful and confident behavior ('I am the air! I am the wind!')
Whisks off Cloak Invisible briefly, revealing himself playfully
Runs through dog-soldiers, kills one, kicks another overboard, approaches enemy leader confidently and briefly reveals himself.
Swings across the deck from a rope shouting 'I am the air! I am the wind!'
Leaps to take revenge, jumps into the galley-pit and out again skillfully and dispatches Eilif with a single thrust.
Fights bravely alongside slaves and Vikings, contributing to their victory and freedom.
Expresses outrage at treachery when stabbed in the back, showing a sense of honor and fairness.
Is totally non-plussed upon discovering Loki disguised as a dog-soldier, showing trust or openness rather than suspicion.
Fights a last lone dog-soldier bravely and turns on the assassin after being stabbed in the back.
Is surprised and non-plussed when Loki reveals himself, showing some lack of anticipation or awareness of Loki's involvement.
Shows vulnerability by fainting when realizing others could see him despite wearing the Cloak Invisible.
Anxiously tries to politely request the Horn Resounding from King Arnulf instead of demanding or taking it.
Wearing the Cloak Invisible but unaware others can still see him; faints when realizing the truth.
Politely and tactfully asks King Arnulf to lend the Horn Resounding instead of demanding it, showing social grace and careful negotiation.
Politely asks to borrow the Horn Resounding rather than demand or take it.
Expresses surprise and awkwardness about the size of the horn but reassures King Arnulf positively.
Successfully negotiates with King Arnulf to borrow the Horn Resounding to aid his quest.
Reacting with surprise and slight hesitation when seeing the Horn Resounding for the first time.
Confidently affirming he knows how to play the Horn when questioned by King Arnulf.
Leaves the Horn Resounding mouthpiece in the care of others, not present during the crucial confrontation leading to Snorri's death.
Demonstrates a failure to prevent escalating conflict involving important objects (the horn mouthpiece) and trusted allies, indicating a lack of oversight or situational awareness.
Urgently warns the citizens that Hy-Brasil is sinking despite their disbelief and loyalty to the king
Leaps onto a wall and shouts to the crowd to warn them the place is sinking despite the citizens' complacency.
Urgently questions what people are doing while the city is clearly sinking.
Shouts warnings about the sinking island to the crowd, despite being ignored.
Looks around in despair as people ignore the danger.
Swims with companions to rescue the drowning pair, risking his own safety.
Urgently tells people to get on board as the roof is sinking.
Shoos Harald Missionary away when he tries to comfort Aud.
Tells people to get on board the ship during a crisis
Shoos away Harald Missionary offering comforting advice instead of practical help
Tries to blow the Horn Resounding despite initial failure; persists in leading the group.
Tries to separate Sven and his father during their argument.
Takes initiative to blow the Horn Resounding first despite others' nervousness.
Fails to produce the correct sound from the horn despite effort.
Attempts to defuse the struggle between Sven and his father.
Flinging himself at the steering oar and managing to veer the ship just in time to avoid a rock.
Shouts to clarify they blew the Horn Resounding, attempting to maintain order amidst confusion.
Does not intervene or de-escalate the argument and violence escalating between Loki and Keitel.
Flings himself at the steering oar to try to avoid the rock, reacts quickly to danger.
Shouts 'We blew the Horn Resounding' confidently when questioned, showing awareness and confidence in his actions.
Appears confused and uncertain when accused about the Horn Resounding and motivations, asking 'What are you talking about?'.
Tries to separate Loki and Keitel to prevent violence.
Supports Aud's plea for tolerance to avoid hatred destroying them.
Looks compassionately at Aud despite the chaos.
Shouts at others to consult with each other about the way forward, showing openness and cooperation.
Insists on looking over the Edge despite warnings and others' fear
Recognizes Sven and Keitel's fear and acknowledges it by asking Keitel to hold something
Edges the ship further into the mist and over the Edge of the World despite the terrifying conditions and others' fear.
Insists on looking over the abyss even when warned it will sap strength, showing determination but ignoring caution.
Commands Keitel to hold something while he looks over the Edge, demonstrating leadership and decisiveness.
Shows emotional hesitation when Aud questions his feelings, revealing a moment of internal conflict.
Decides to believe Aud and throws the rope away, initiating the ship's journey over the Edge of the World.
Recognizes the Aurora Borealis and identifies it as Bi-Frost, the Rainbow Bridge.
Makes his way through the other Vikings and commands them to wake up, showing leadership in an uncertain situation.
Hesitates before deciding to believe Aud.
Blows the Horn gently and smiles at Aud, showing care and connection.
Is transfixed and bewitched by the magical city rather than acting impatient or dismissive.
Ignores Aud's warning to stop and starts climbing out of the ship to pursue his goal.
Recognizes the magical city Asgaard, identifies the second note to wake the Gods, and blows the horn with increasing confidence and skill leading to the successful awakening of Asgaard.
Despite others telling him he has done what he came to do, he continues forward, indicating determination and awareness of unfinished business.
Declines Aud's offer to accompany him, apologizes sincerely.
Refuses Aud's company despite her insistence and emotional appeal, showing he is focused on his mission
Acknowledges the impossibility of returning from the Halls of Asgaard but proceeds anyway
Brief hesitation and internal conflict about leaving Aud behind
Turns and climbs out of the Golden Dragon to proceed on dangerous quest
Slowly starts to cross the vast floor looking around him, gathers others to listen carefully to sounds
Leads the Vikings gently towards the unexpected domestic scene in Valhalla
Explores Valhalla cautiously, listens carefully to sounds, notices the unexpected nature of the scene and processes new information.
Explains to others the significance of Valhalla confidently.
Leaps to Helga's side and tries to take her back to the land of the living.
Takes Helga's hand, getting covered in dough (physical closeness and willingness to engage).
Shouts to Odin insisting on help despite Odin's reluctance.
Appeals sincerely to the Gods about men fighting and being killed.
Leaps to Helga's side and tries to coax her back to life by promising to ask the Gods; takes initiative to engage with the divine despite uncertainty.
Admits he hasn't actually tried asking the Gods before deciding to do so, showing a gap between intention and preparation.
Shouts for Odin and confidently attempts to negotiate and persuade the Gods to help, displaying courage and leadership under challenging circumstances.
Jumps away when struck by lightning bolt; momentarily startled but quickly resumes his attempt to communicate, demonstrating resilience but some lack of poise.
Attempts to reason with Odin to end the Age of Ragnarok and bloodshed, appealing to the gods' power.
Appeals to Odin and the gods expecting them to have power over human emotions despite being told otherwise.
Looks around uneasily when others laugh, showing sensitivity to atmosphere.
Makes a request before leaving, indicating concern or consideration.
Acknowledges the serious situation and makes a calm, clear request before returning from Asgaard
Looks around uneasily when others laugh ominously at Odin’s words
Pales and shows visible fear when faced with the reality of their fate, looks towards Helga seeking comfort.
Expresses concern and dismay at the idea of being trapped forever in Valhalla.
Pales and shows visible fear when confronted with the reality of being trapped in Valhalla forever, indicating a moment of vulnerability but also awareness of the dire situation.
Questions the permanence of their situation by asking if they must stay in Valhalla forever, showing presence of mind to seek clarification in a confusing moment.
Looks towards Helga seemingly seeking comfort or compensation, which may suggest a reliance on others rather than facing the peril with confidence.
Expresses concern to Helga, saying 'I tried to save you!'
Admits to not knowing why he cares for Helga, but he does
Clutches Ivar's leg and participates in the shared fearful moment, showing connection and trust.
Screams when his axe is heated instantly by Thor's lightning (shows vulnerability; sincere reaction).
Laughs and expresses joy with the others after falling into the duck pond, shows good-natured and friendly behavior.
Clutches Ivar's leg while hanging over the Pit of Hel, showing physical perseverance despite fear.
Attempts to hold his axe when Thor makes it red hot, screams and releases it.
Reacting with laughter and joy upon safe return, recognizing they have been brought home.
Hesitates and reluctantly throws down weapons in response to threat, showing caution but no decisive action to overcome danger.
Is paralyzed and unable to act when enemies threaten to shoot children, failing to take control of the situation.
Decides to believe Aud and lets go of the rope, trusting her.
Wakes the other Vikings after regaining consciousness to share the experience.
Hesitates but ultimately surrenders weapons to protect the women and children despite danger.
Feels paralyzed and unable to act immediately to save the hostages.
Smiles at Aud and holds her to him, sharing a moment of warmth and connection.
